case_name: Criminal Appeals Nos. 209 of 1962 and 3 of 1963

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 209 of 1962 and 3 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 209 of 1962 and 3 of 1963. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 30, 1962, of the Patna High Court in Government Appeal No. 33 of 1959 and Cr. Appeal No. 392 of 1959 respectively.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 30, 1962, of the Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 30, 1962, of the Patna High Court in Government Appeal No. 33 of 1959 and Cr. Appeal No. 392 of 1959 respectively. P. Varma, for the appellants  in Cr. A. No. 209 of 62 .

facts.text: Government Appeal No. 33 of 1959 and Cr. Appeal No. 392 of 1959 in Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Patna High Court in Government Appeal No. 33 of 1959 and Cr. Appeal No. 392 of 1959 respectively. P. Varma, for the appellants  in Cr. A. No. 209 of 62 . K. Sinha, for the appellants  in Cr. A. No. 3 of 1963 .

facts.text: Nine persons convicted under s. 302/149, Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: In these two appeals by nine persons, who, have been companyvicted under s. 302/1149, Indian Penal Code, special. leave is limited to one question of law, namely, whether the accused companyld be legally companyvicted under the above sections when they were number charged and companyvicted under S. 147 or s. 148 of the Indian Penal Code ?

facts.text: Special leave limited to question whether accused could be convicted under s. 302/149 without being charged under s. 147 or s. 148.

anchor.surface_text: In these two appeals by nine persons, who, have been companyvicted under s. 302/1149, Indian Penal Code, special. leave is limited to one question of law, namely, whether the accused companyld be legally companyvicted under the above sections when they were number charged and companyvicted under S. 147 or s. 148 of the Indian Penal Code ? It appears from the judgment under appeal that there was a difference of opinion on this point in the High Court at Patna

facts.text: Patna High Court Full Bench held charges under ss. 147 and 148 not necessary before conviction under s. 302 with aid of s. 149.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the judgment under appeal that there was a difference of opinion on this point in the High Court at Patna and the appeals in the High Court were disposed of by a Full Bench which held that charges under ss. 147 and 148 were number necessary before companyviction under s. 302, Indian Penal Code companyld be made with the aid of s. 149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Misari lost his life and was related to some of the accused persons.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the limited nature of the appeals only the essential facts may be stated. The person who lost As life was one Misari who was related to some of the accused persons. In the past there were other incidents.

facts.text: In 1955 one Ajablal was murdered and some of the present accused were prosecuted but acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: In the past there were other incidents. In 1955 one Ajablal was murdered and some of the present accused were prosecuted but were acquitted. Subsequently, one Baldeo Sharma was murdered and some of the prosecution witnesses in this case were charged with that offence.

facts.text: Baldeo Sharma was murdered and some prosecution witnesses charged; appeal pending in Patna High Court as of August 30, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, one Baldeo Sharma was murdered and some of the prosecution witnesses in this case were charged with that offence. At the time of the judgment under appeal  August 30, 1962  an appeal was pending in the Patna High Court against the companyviction of the accused in that case.

facts.text: Present occurrence took place on April 24, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The present occurrence took place on April 24, 1958. The prosecution case is that Misari was going in the morning to call laborers when he was attacked by the appellants with diverse weapons.

facts.text: Misari was going in the morning to call laborers when attacked by appellants with diverse weapons.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that Misari was going in the morning to call laborers when he was attacked by the appellants with diverse weapons. He died as a result of his injuries and a case was registered under s. 302, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Misari died as a result of his injuries; case registered under s. 302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: He died as a result of his injuries and a case was registered under s. 302, Indian Penal Code. The appellants were charged at the trial alternatively under s. 302/149 and 302 /34, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellants charged alternatively under s. 302/149 and 302/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were charged at the trial alternatively under s. 302/149 and 302 /34, Indian Penal Code. The Additional Sessions Judge, Monahyr companyvicted three of the appellant,-, on both the charges, sentencing them to imprisonment for life on the first charge only.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Monahyr convicted three appellants on both charges, life imprisonment on first charge; remaining accused acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Sessions Judge, Monahyr companyvicted three of the appellant,-, on both the charges, sentencing them to imprisonment for life on the first charge only. The remaining accused were acquitted. Appeals by those who were companyvicted and by the State Government against the acquittal of the others were heard together

facts.text: Appeals by convicted accused and State Government against acquittals heard together, disposed by common judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining accused were acquitted. Appeals by those who were companyvicted and by the State Government against the acquittal of the others were heard together and were disposed of by the companymon judgment number under appeal.

facts.text: State Government appeal allowed; appeals of three convicted accused dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal of the State Government was allowed and that of the three companyvicted accused was dismissed. As a result all the original accused were companyvicted under s. 302/1.49, Indian Penal Code

facts.text: All original accused convicted under s. 302/149 IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: As a result all the original accused were companyvicted under s. 302/1.49, Indian Penal Code and were sentenced to imprisonment for life. During the hearing of the appeals a point was raised by the State companynsel

facts.text: During appeals hearing, State counsel raised point that trial bad for no charge under s. 147 or 148.

anchor.surface_text: During the hearing of the appeals a point was raised by the State companynsel in the appeal by the State that the trial was bad inasmuch as numbercharge under S. 147 or s. 148 had been framed. The Divisional Bench thinking that the point might

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with Full Bench conclusion and confirms judgment under appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the companyclusion of the Full Bench and therefore companyfirm the judgment under appeal.

facts.text: Prosecution proved existence of unlawful assembly, common object to murder Misari, and membership of each appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The charges that are framed against the appellants and which we have reproduced earlier, companytain all the necessary ingredients to bring home to each member of the unlawful assembly the offence of murder with the aid of s. 149. The prosecution has proved the existence of an unlawful assembly, its companymon object which was murder of Misari and the member-,hip of each of the appellants.

Section 141 defines an unlawful assembly as an assembly of five or more persons the companymon object of which is inter alia to companymit an offence. There are five clauses which describe the many kinds of companymon objects which render an assembly unlawful.

concepts.interpretation: Defines unlawful assembly; common object to commit murder proved here

anchor.surface_text: Continuing again with the scheme of the Chapter, we next see that s. 142 says that a person is companysidered to be a member of an unlawful assembly, if, being aware of facts which render any assembly an unlawful assembly be intentionally joins that assembly or companytinues in it.

A mere membership of an unlawful assembly is punishable under S. 143. Under the next section heavier punishment is awardable to a person who joins an unlawful assembly armed with a deadly weapon or with anything which used as a weapon of offence is likely to cause death.

anchor.surface_text: Section 145 next provides for a similar higher punishment for a person who joins or companytinues in an unlawful assembly knowing that it has been ordered to disperse. These sections make mem- bership as such of an unlawful assembly punishable, though in varying degrees.

anchor.surface_text: This being the scheme, is it obligatory to charge a person under s. 147 or s. 148 before s. 149 can be utilized ? Section 149 does number state this to be a companydition precedent for its own application. No other section prescribes this procedure.

arguments.claim: It is not obligatory to charge a person under s. 147 or s. 148 before s. 149 can be utilized
Sections 146 and 149 represent conditions under which vicarious liability arises for the acts of others without requiring prior charges
It is not obligatory to charge a person under s. 143 or s. 147 when charging him for an offence with the aid of s. 149; these sections are implied
The fallacy in cases holding charge under s. 147 compulsory overlooks that ingredients of s. 147 are implied in charge under s. 149
The charges framed contain all necessary ingredients to bring home offence of murder with aid of s. 149; prosecution proved unlawful assembly, common object, membership

anchor.surface_text: The charges that are framed against the appellants and which we have reproduced earlier, contain all the necessary ingredients to bring home to each member of the unlawful assembly the offence of murder with the aid of s. 149. The prosecution has proved

arguments.claim: If charge under s. 147 or 148 failed, then s. 149 could not be used; but separate charges not condition precedent

anchor.surface_text: Nothing more was necessary. of course, if a charge had been framed under S. 147 or 148 and that charge had failed against any of the accused then s. 149 could not have been used against him.

arguments.claim: There can be proof under s. 149 of unlawful assembly, common object, participation same as under ss. 143, 147, 148; other charges not condition precedent

anchor.surface_text: There can be proof under s. 149 of the existence of an unlawful assembly, of the common object and of the part played by the unlawful assembly or any of its members, same as under s. 143 or S. 147 or s. 148. There may be additional charges

holdings.text: charges under ss. 147 and 148 were not necessary before conviction under s. 302, Indian Penal Code could be made with the aid of s. 149, Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the judgment under appeal that there was a difference of opinion on this point in the High Court at Patna and the appeals in the High Court were disposed of by a Full Bench which held that charges under ss. 147 and 148 were not necessary before conviction under s. 302, Indian Penal Code could be made with the aid of s. 149, Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full Bench conclusion adopted by Supreme Court after statutory scheme analysis; no condition precedent in s.149 or elsewhere

holdings.text: We agree with the conclusion of the Full Bench and therefore confirm the judgment under appeal

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the conclusion of the Full Bench and therefore confirm the judgment under appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit adoption of lower court ratio on no need for ss.147/148 charges prior to s.302/149 conviction

holdings.text: is it obligatory to charge a person under s. 147 or s. 148 before s. 149 can be utilized ? Section 149 does not state this to be a condition precedent for its own application. No other section prescribes this procedure.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Chapter VIII IPC shows s.149 operates independently without requiring prior rioting charges

holdings.text: It is not obligatory to charge a person under s. 143 or s. 147 when charging him for an offence with the aid of s. 149. These sections are implied.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Progressive implication of ingredients from s.141 onwards in higher sections; no separate framing needed

anchor.surface_text: The charges that are framed against the appellants and which we have reproduced earlier, contain all the necessary ingredients to bring home to each member of the unlawful assembly the offence of murder with the aid of s. 149. The prosecution has proved the existence of an unlawful assembly, its common object which was murder of Misari and the membership of each of the appellants.
